question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: What sports league was Steve Shephard competing in in 2010?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Steve Shephard**

Steve Shephard is a former American college basketball player who played in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league from 1994 to 1999. **College Career**

Shephard attended Boise State University, where he played for the Boise State Broncos men's basketball team from 1994 to 1999. During his time at Boise State, the team competed in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league, which is the highest level of college basketball in the United States. **NCAA Division I Men's Basketball**

The NCAA Division I men's basketball league is a college sports league in the United States that consists of 358 teams from colleges and universities across the country. The league is governed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) and is considered the premier level of college basketball in the United States. **Evidence**

According to the Boise State University Athletics website, Steve Shephard played for the Boise State Broncos men's basketball team from 1994 to 1999. [1] Additionally, the NCAA website lists Boise State University as a member institution of the NCAA Division I men's basketball league during the same period. [2]

Furthermore, multiple sports news outlets, including the Idaho Statesman and the Deseret News, reported on Shephard's performances and achievements during his time playing for Boise State in the NCAA Division I men's basketball league. [3][4]

**References**

[1] Boise State University Athletics. (n.d.). Steve Shephard. Retrieved from <https:\/\/broncosports.com\/sports\/mens-basketball\/roster\/steve-shephard\/1994>

[2] National Collegiate Athletic Association. (n.d.). NCAA Division I Members. Retrieved from <https:\/\/www.ncaa.org\/about\/resources\/media-center\/ncaa-division-i-members>

[3] Idaho Statesman. (1997, February 22). Shephard leads Broncos past Nevada. Retrieved from <https:\/\/news.google.com\/newspapers?id=VXRPAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6wIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6934,4118118&dq=steve+shephard+boise+state&hl=en>

[4] Deseret News. (1998, March 1). Shephard's 23 points lead Boise State past Utah State.
content.source_2:
**BREAKING NEWS**

Former College Hoops Star Steve Shephard Hangs Up Skates After Illustrious 17-Year NHL Career

In a shocking announcement yesterday, Steve Shephard, the former Boise State college basketball standout, revealed his retirement from professional hockey, bringing an end to an incredible 17-year career in the National Hockey League. Shephard, who made the unconventional transition from the hardwood to the ice in 2027, defied all odds to become one of the most beloved and respected players in the NHL. The 6'5" forward played for five different teams, including the Vegas Golden Knights, Toronto Maple Leafs, and Pittsburgh Penguins, amassing an impressive 542 points (234 goals, 308 assists) in 1,042 regular-season games. "I'm grateful for the opportunity to have played the game I love for so long," Shephard said in an emotional press conference at the NHL headquarters in New York City. "From the moment I laced up my skates, I knew I had found my true calling. The NHL has given me so much, and I'm proud to have been a part of it." Shephard's journey to the NHL was nothing short of remarkable. After a successful college basketball career at Boise State from 1994 to 1999, he took a chance on hockey, enrolling in a developmental program in his mid-20s. His hard work and dedication paid off, as he earned a spot on the Golden Knights' roster in 2027. "Steve's story is an inspiration to anyone who's ever doubted themselves," said NHL Commissioner, Gary Bettman. "He proved that with perseverance and passion, anything is possible. We're going to miss him on the ice, but we're excited to see what the future holds for him." Throughout his career, Shephard was known for his tireless work ethic, clutch performances, and charitable endeavors. He was a four-time NHL All-Star and won the Mark Messier Leadership Award in 2035. As he embarks on the next chapter of his life, Shephard plans to remain involved in the hockey community, focusing on youth development programs and advocating for diversity and inclusion in the sport. "I'm excited to give back to the game that has given me so much," Shephard said. "I want to help create opportunities for kids from all backgrounds to experience the joy of hockey."
